Winsen has a population of around 12,900 and lies on the southern edge of the
, close to the huge military training area of Bergen-Hohne. It is about 15 kilometres northwest of the county town of

. Within the borough of Winsen are the villages of Bannetze, Meißendorf, Stedden, Südwinsen, Thören, Walle and Wolthausen.

Winsen's church is dedicated to John the Baptist which is a clue to when it was founded. All other  villages with churches named after John the Baptist appeared around AD 800.

Today Winsen is a popular local recreation and holiday sport and is an official climatic health spa (
railway where there are hourly Intercity (IC) trains to both cities as well as ICE trains during the rush hour. Celle is also the terminus of routes S 6 and S 7 of the Hanover S-Bahn.
Winsen is at the crossroads of the north-south L298 state road from Bergen to Ovelgönne, and the east-west L180 from Celle to Bannetze.

value: . Exit at Junction 52, "Mellendorf", and head for Celle. After 7 km, turn L just after Allerhop onto the L298 to Winsen (Aller).
. Exit at Junction 53, "Schwarmstedt", and head for Celle on the B214. At Ovelgönne, turn L onto the L298 to Winsen (Aller).

Winsen has a compact town centre just north of the River Aller which is easy to get around on foot. Most of the sights and places to eat in the town itself are walkable from the centre.

value: Church of St. John the Baptist
, probably built in the 9th century, but since extended.

), by the track between Winsen and Oldau recall a decisive battle on 28 May 1388 during the Lüneburg War of Succession. According to legend two princes wounded each other mortally at this spot before they realised they were brothers.
) built on the site of the original district office that had to be demolished. The present building is a baroque affair dating to the 18th century.

content=A great little open-air museum which gives a flavour of life on a Lower Saxon farm in past centuries. Not very expensive and they have a guide sheet in English. The adjacent café (see below) in an old farmhouse is great and the cakes are good enough to rival those at the much more famous

As a small country town, Winsen has all the basics, but for serious shopping you need to go to Celle, or even Hanover.

value: Café Herrenhaus Gut Sunder in the old manor house
content= Great ice-creams and in summer you can sit outside and watch the storks nesting opposite.
directions=By the Winsen Farm Museum in Winsen

directions=From crossroads in centre of Winsen, take rd to Celle. After 2½ km turn L to Wolthausen. After 2 km, turn R in Wolthausen onto B3. Heideschenke on R just before bridge.

content=Pricey and the menu is limited, but outstandingly good (try the hare) and the manager speaks English. For those special occasions.
directions=From crossroads in centre of Winsen, head N along Poststr. After 250m turn L into Meißendorfer Str. In centre of Meißendorf, turn L onto Bruchstr. and follow signs to Gut Sunder.
content=Quiet little café in the old manor house. Relax outside on a lazy summer's day under the shade of the trees and enjoy a tea or coffee and delicious cakes such as the local
, whilst watching your kids frolic in the children's play park. Find out about the variety of nature walks in the area from the local NABU information centre. Not far from the
lake where there is a popular circular walk around this bird and wildlife haven.
content=4 star, timber-framed courtyard hotel with 29 rooms, wellness suite, massage and cosmetic room, 50 seater restaurant and lounges. Facilities for horses.
content=Medium-priced hotel in the centre of Winsen with a restaurant, pub, bowling alley and dance school.
price=Under €20 for a campervan (including 2 persons, electricity)
content=A family run camping site along the river Aller, suitable also as a base for canoeing trips, riding (horses rental at the site) and cycling.
Greylag Geese on one of the Meißendorf lakes

, a nature reserve and bird sanctuary centred on lakes that used to be a huge network of ponds built to farm fish. Circular walk round the main lake. A bird hide has good views of the cormorant colony and countless water fowl and birds of prey. A short walk away in the woods is
a former manor house; now a café (see above) and wildlife information centre.
10 mins drive from Winsen on the B214
). Open Tu-Su and PH. Mar-May 10am-5pm, Jun-Aug 10am-6pm, Sep-Nov 10am-5pm. Tel: +49 (5146) 92341.

. More interesting than it sounds, the German Oil Museum describes how local farmers scooped oil from tar pits and sold it for lubrication and medicinal purposes. Later over 2,000 wells were bored in the area and it became a major industry. €5 (''Family tickets €9, concessions €2.50, under 6 go free).
